title: High Weald Landscape Trail Walking Route

images.title: Peter Cox / Sheepwash  Ghyll, St Leonard's Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sheepwash Ghyll, St Leonard's Forest. Sheepwash Ghyll has cut a deep ravine running over a base of sandstone often forming small 'waterfalls' as here and providing a ford for the footpath going up Scragged Oak Hill (to the right). Sheepwash Ghyll flows out of Whitevane Pond, about 1.5km to the north of this photo, through Roosthole Pond and as Goldings stream into (Birchen) Mill Pond. Flowing out of (Birchen) Mill Pond and under the A281 it emerges as the river Arun on its way to the sea at Littlehampton.

images.title: Vernon Dunhill / Smallhythe Place, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Smallhythe Place near Tenterden. Home of the Victorian actress Ellen Terry

images.title: Michael FORD [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Borde Hill

images.caption: Wakehurst Place

images.title: David Anstiss / The High Weald Landscape Trail leads past The Park
images.caption: The High Weald Landscape Trail leads past The Park in Cranbrook. The long distance path heads from Cranbrook past land around Oak Hill Manor. In the background it turns right (see other walkers) heading towards Baker's Cross.

description: Explore the High Weald AONB on this fabulous 90 mile walk that links the ridge-top villages and historic gardens for which the area is famous. The walk starts at the rail station in Horsham, West Sussex, and heads east to Rye in East Sussex. Walk highlights include
